questions.question: What is the law of reflection?
options: Angle of incidence = Angle of reflection
questions.explanation: The law of reflection states that when light hits a surface, the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection.

questions.question: What is the normal line in reflection?
options: An imaginary line perpendicular to the surface
A line parallel to the surface
questions.explanation: The normal is an imaginary line drawn perpendicular to the reflecting surface at the point of incidence, used to measure angles.

questions.question: What type of reflection occurs from smooth surfaces like mirrors?
questions.explanation: Regular reflection occurs from smooth surfaces where parallel light rays remain parallel after reflection, creating clear images.

questions.question: Why can we see most objects around us?
options: They reflect light into our eyes
questions.explanation: Most objects are visible because they reflect light from light sources into our eyes.

questions.question: What type of mirror always creates virtual images?
questions.explanation: Plane mirrors (flat mirrors) always create virtual images that appear behind the mirror and cannot be projected on a screen.

questions.question: What is the image characteristics in a plane mirror?
questions.explanation: Plane mirrors produce virtual images that are upright, the same size as the object, and appear to be behind the mirror.

questions.question: Why is the image in a plane mirror reversed left-to-right but not up-down?
questions.explanation: The reversal is actually front-to-back, not left-to-right. When you face a mirror, your front becomes your back in the image.

questions.question: What type of mirror is used in car side mirrors?
questions.explanation: Convex mirrors are used in car side mirrors because they provide a wider field of view, though images appear smaller.

questions.question: What type of mirror can focus light to a point?
questions.explanation: Concave mirrors (curved inward) can converge parallel light rays to a focal point.

questions.question: Where are concave mirrors commonly used?
questions.explanation: Concave mirrors are used in makeup mirrors (for magnification), satellite dishes, and telescope mirrors to collect and focus light.

questions.question: What is the focal point of a concave mirror?
options: Where parallel rays converge after reflection
questions.explanation: The focal point is where parallel light rays converging after reflecting from a concave mirror meet.

questions.question: Why do convex mirrors show a wider field of view?
options: They are larger than other mirrors
questions.explanation: Convex mirrors curve outward, causing light rays to diverge after reflection, which allows viewing a larger area.

questions.question: What type of image do convex mirrors always produce?
questions.explanation: Convex mirrors always produce virtual images that are upright and smaller than the object.

questions.question: Why does diffuse reflection allow us to see non-shiny objects?
options: Rough surfaces scatter light in all directions
questions.explanation: Rough surfaces cause diffuse reflection, scattering light in many directions so we can see the object from any angle.

questions.question: What is the difference between real and virtual images?
options: Real images can be projected, virtual cannot
questions.explanation: Real images form where light actually converges and can be projected on a screen. Virtual images appear where light seems to come from but doesn't actually converge there.

questions.question: How many images are formed when two mirrors are placed at 90 degrees?
questions.explanation: When two mirrors are at 90 degrees, they form 3 images of an object placed between them due to multiple reflections.

questions.question: What is periscope principle based on?
questions.explanation: Periscopes use two mirrors arranged at 45 degrees to reflect light twice, allowing viewing over obstacles.

questions.question: Why do mirrors appear to reverse left and right but not up and down?
options: Because we rotate around vertical axis
Our eyes are side by side
questions.explanation: When you face a mirror and raise your right hand, the image raises its left hand because you've mentally rotated yourself to face the same direction as your image.

questions.question: What happens to light energy during reflection?
options: Most is reflected, some is absorbed
questions.explanation: During reflection, most light is reflected but some energy is always absorbed by the material, which is why no mirror is 100% efficient.

questions.question: Why are emergency vehicle mirrors convex?
options: To see wider areas for safety
questions.explanation: Convex mirrors on emergency vehicles provide a wider field of view, helping drivers see more of their surroundings for safety.
